content: The "Fairness for America's Servicemen and Women in Higher Education Act of 2003" allows students on active duty during a war or national emergency to withdraw from higher education without repaying grant assistance. The "Fairness for America's Servicemen and Women in Higher Education Act of 2003" allows students on active duty during a war or national emergency to withdraw from higher education without repaying grant assistance. An amendment to the Higher Education Act of 1965 now includes provisions for FFEL Subsidized Loans for borrowers who are members of the military on active duty during a war or national emergency, receiving specified compensation. The "Fairness for America's Servicemen and Women in Higher Education Act of 2003" allows students on active duty during a war or national emergency to withdraw from higher education without repaying grant assistance. Members of the military on active duty during a war or national emergency are eligible for FFEL Subsidized Loans. The "Fairness for America's Servicemen and Women in Higher Education Act of 2003" allows military members on active duty during a national emergency to withdraw from higher education without repaying grant assistance. This Act also makes them eligible for FFEL Subsidized Loans. The new subparagraph allows borrowers on active duty during a war or national emergency to receive compensation and be eligible for FFEL Subsidized Loans. The new subparagraph allows borrowers on active duty during a war or national emergency to receive compensation and be eligible for FFEL Subsidized Loans, regardless of the location or duration of their service. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is being amended to allow for consolidation loans for students on active duty deferment and FFEL Unsubsidized Loans for borrowers on active duty during a war or national emergency. The Education Act of 1965 is amended to require the Secretary to pay interest on loans for students on active duty deferment. This applies to Direct Unsubsidized Loans and Perkins Loans. The Education Act of 1965 is amended to require the Secretary to pay interest on loans for students on active duty deferment, including specific conditions during war or national emergencies. The Education Act of 1965 is amended to require the Secretary to pay interest on loans for students on active duty deferment, including specific conditions during war or national emergencies, as outlined in various sections of the United States Code. The Education Act of 1965 is amended to require the Secretary to pay interest on loans for students on active duty deferment for more than 30 consecutive days under specific sections of the United States Code in response to a national emergency declared by the President. Effective July 1, 1993, the amendments apply to new borrowers. The Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1003) is amended to require the Secretary to pay interest on loans for students on active duty deferment for more than 30 consecutive days in response to a national emergency declared by the President. Effective July 1, 1993, the amendments apply to new borrowers.
